description.narrative: The Recipient will, during the first year of the project, (1) identify law enforcement (LE) and law enforcement monitoring (LEM) training needs in southeast Asian range states, (2) provide training at their MIKE sites as necessary, (3) facilitate and support regular LE and LEM activities at MIKE sites, (4) facilitate regular elephant population monitoring at MIKE sites in southeast Asia using standard peer-reviewed survey methods, (5) conduct a pilot study on the effectiveness of detection dogs to locate elephant feces and carcasses, as well as snares, poachers camps, and other signs of illegal activity in forests in Asia and Africa, and (6) conduct and facilitate training of range state government agency staff in elephant population survey methods and data analysis and reporting skills.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Direct cross-regional support for elephant range States to help them meet their obligations under the CITES Monitoring the Illegal Killing of Elephants (MIKE) Project: carcass detection, law enforcement, population monitoring, and capacity-building

description.narrative: The Recipient will, during the first year of the project, (1) identify law enforcement (LE) and law enforcement monitoring (LEM) training needs in southeast Asian range states, (2) provide training at their MIKE sites as necessary, (3) facilitate and support regular LE and LEM activities at MIKE sites, (4) facilitate regular elephant population monitoring at MIKE sites in southeast Asia using standard peer-reviewed survey methods, (5) conduct a pilot study on the effectiveness of detection dogs to locate elephant feces and carcasses, as well as snares, poachers camps, and other signs of illegal activity in forests in Asia and Africa, and (6) conduct and facilitate training of range state government agency staff in elephant population survey methods and data analysis and reporting skills.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to enhance conservation education and strengthen local capacity by training a new cadre of researchers, educators, and practitioners skilled at integrative research and intervention focused on zoonotic disease emergence. A one week training course on Emerging Zoonotic Diseases (EZD) Short Course, including a field component, will focus on the emergence of diseases from wildlife reservoirs and how strategic wildlife conservation effort can help mitigate risks of disease spillover, and benefits of wildlife conservation. The EZD Short Course curriculum combines knowledge and methods from veterinary and medical science, microbiology, epidemiology, medical geography, disease ecology, environmental risk management, ecosystem management, and conservation biology. The intended target will be veterinary faculty, though a small minority may not have veterinary degrees. Participants will have a background and/or strong interest in wildlife and in applying One Health to their research and teaching. In addition, the participant will require formal endorsement of their administration and a statement that these efforts to integrate One Health within the veterinary curriculum will be supported, including the cooperation of the veterinary faculty as a whole. Participants will be selected from Southeast Asian countries.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Assessing orangutan density with unmanned aerial vehicles: testing a new method along the..Kinabatangan river (Sabah, Malaysia)

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to conduct a set of aerial UAV and helicopter and ground surveys so that it can be determined whether the UAV surveys can provide similar density estimates as those from ground and helicopter surveys and whether a fully automated system to detect nests can be used to assess orangutan status not only in Kinabatangan, but throughout Borneo.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Siamese ivory trails: Asian market surveys to understand regional ivory flows if CITES action to close the Thai ivory market succeeds

description.narrative: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) as countries of concern (Thailand, Cambodia, Lao PDR, Myanmar, Viet Nam, and the three southernmost mainland Chinese provinces). Specifically, the grantee will 1) undertake retail ivory market surveys in specific market and urban areas, 2) assess national legislation, policies and law enforcement capabilities and efficacy of actions for ivory trade with regard to the national ivory action plans, 3) draft recommendations to address areas of concern, 4) produce and publish detailed, systematic updated ivory trade studies for the public and for the CITES Secretariat, Standing Committee, and other stakeholders, and 5) integrate market survey data in the Domestic Ivory Market Database of the Elephant Trade Information System (ETIS).

title.narrative: Siamese ivory trails: Asian market surveys to understand regional ivory flows if CITES action to close the Thai ivory market succeeds

description.narrative: This project will analyze ivory markets, ivory trade legislation and policy and law enforcement capacity in six consumer countries identified by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) as countries of concern (Thailand, Cambodia, Lao PDR, Myanmar, Viet Nam, and the three southernmost mainland Chinese provinces). Specifically, the grantee will 1) undertake retail ivory market surveys in specific market and urban areas, 2) assess national legislation, policies and law enforcement capabilities and efficacy of actions for ivory trade with regard to the national ivory action plans, 3) draft recommendations to address areas of concern, 4) produce and publish detailed, systematic updated ivory trade studies for the public and for the CITES Secretariat, Standing Committee, and other stakeholders, and 5) integrate market survey data in the Domestic Ivory Market Database of the Elephant Trade Information System (ETIS).

title.narrative: Strengthening CITIES Compliance and Law Enforcement in Southeast Asian Parties.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support key Parties in Southeast Asia in their efforts to improve their CITES compliance and enforcement systems in areas where needs have been expressed, and thereby support their efforts in tackling illegal trade in wildlife.

title.narrative: Evaluation of Bornean orangutan conservation action plans: Impacts and recommendations

description.narrative: The project has the following objectives: (1) Analyze the impacts of existing action plan implementation on Bornean orangutan populations; (2) Develop recommendations for future planning based on evaluation results and best available science; and, (3) Improve new action plans with evaluation findings and recommendations.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: FACILITATING HUMAN-ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE THROUGH REGENERATIVE AGRO-ECOLOGY IN INDIA, SRI LANKA, THAILAND, AND CAMBODIA

description.narrative: This project will evaluate the potential of alternative crops as a market-based approach to.converting elephants from liability to asset by developing products from botanical derivatives. This.approach will be experimentally tested in two different countries representing different cultures and.ecological contexts to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of building a self-sustaining model for.conservation through human-elephant coexistence (HECx) on agricultural landscapes. Project objectives.are to: (1) identify suitable crops and botanical species at each site based on their ecological attributes and.market potential; (2) develop a supply chain linking producers with sellers and customers; (3) engage.participants and obtain baseline data on each participants location in preparation for controlled.experiments; and (4) test the alternative crop approach for facilitating HECx. Year one project activities.are to: (1) compile a detailed report on botanicals, their requirements, and markets; (2) conduct financial.analyses working with prospective enterprise partners; (3) conduct meetings with stakeholders and.authorities to set expectations and identify available resources; (4) identify sources for seedlings and or.build nurseries at each site; (5) finalize study locations and participants and assign them to experimental.or control groups; (6) design community questionnaire protocols and conduct surveys at each site; (7).collect baseline ecological field data; and (8) collect and analyze satellite imagery for selected sites..Project activities for year two are to: (1) provide supplies for and monitor the intervention group.participating farmers; (2) identify suppliers and facilitate provision of support for control group.communities; (3) set up and monitor camera traps on agricultural lands; and (4) consolidate data and.summarize results from all sites.

title.narrative: FACILITATING HUMAN-ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE THROUGH REGENERATIVE AGRO-ECOLOGY IN INDIA, SRI LANKA, THAILAND, AND CAMBODIA

description.narrative: THIS PROJECT WILL EVALUATE THE POTENTIAL OF ALTERNATIVE CROPS AS A MARKET BASED APPROACH TO CONVERTING ELEPHANTS FROM LIABILITY TO ASSET BY DEVELOPING PRODUCTS FROM BOTANICAL DERIVATIVES. THIS APPROACH WILL BE EXPERIMENTALLY TESTED IN TWO DIFFERENT COUNTRIES REPRESENTING DIFFERENT CULTURES AND ECOLOGICAL CONTEXTS TO EVALUATE THE FEASIBILITY AND EFFICACY OF BUILDING A SELF SUSTAINING MODEL FOR CONSERVATION THROUGH HUMAN ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE (HECX) ON AGRICULTURAL LANDSCAPES. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) IDENTIFY SUITABLE CROPS AND BOTANICAL SPECIES AT EACH SITE BASED ON THEIR ECOLOGICAL ATTRIBUTES AND MARKET POTENTIAL (2) DEVELOP A SUPPLY CHAIN LINKING PRODUCERS WITH SELLERS AND CUSTOMERS (3) ENGAGE PARTICIPANTS AND OBTAIN BASELINE DATA ON EACH PARTICIPANTS LOCATION IN PREPARATION FOR CONTROLLED EXPERIMENTS AND (4) TEST THE ALTERNATIVE CROP APPROACH FOR FACILITATING HECX. YEAR ONE PROJECT ACTIVITIES ARE TO (1) COMPILE A DETAILED REPORT ON BOTANICALS, THEIR REQUIREMENTS, AND MARKETS (2) CONDUCT FINANCIAL ANALYSES WORKING WITH PROSPECTIVE ENTERPRISE PARTNERS (3) CONDUCT MEETINGS WITH STAKEHOLDERS AND AUTHORITIES TO SET EXPECTATIONS AND IDENTIFY AVAILABLE RESOURCES (4) IDENTIFY SOURCES FOR SEEDLINGS AND OR BUILD NURSERIES AT EACH SITE (5) FINALIZE STUDY LOCATIONS AND PARTICIPANTS AND ASSIGN THEM TO EXPERI

title.narrative: BUILDING REGIONAL CAPACITY FOR GENETIC RESEARCH TO SUPPORT ASIA-PACIFIC MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT.

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BUILD CAPACITY FOR GENETICS RESEARCH IN THE ASIA-PACIFIC TO SUPPORT MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION ISSUES RELATED TO TRAFFICKING AND IDENTIFICATION OF SOURCE POPULATIONS AND DETERMINING GENETIC AND DEMOGRAPHICALLY DISTINCT MANAGEMENT UNITS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE 1 GENETICS TRAINING WORKSHOP FOR AT LEAST SIX GRADUATE STUDENTS AND RESEARCHERS FROM THE PHILIPPINES, INDONESIA AND VIETNAM 2 ORGANIZING AND FACILITATING IN-PERSON MEETINGS TO FOSTER REGIONAL COLLABORATION 3 CREATING AND UPDATING THE REGIONAL ROOKERY BASELINE FOR HAWKSBILLS, LEATHERBACKS AND GREEN TURTLE POPULATIONS USING NEW AND PREVIOUS TISSUE BLOOD SAMPLES AND 4 TRACING ORIGINS OF SEA TURTLES AND SHELLS PRODUCTS IN THE ILLEGAL TRADE FROM SEIZED SAMPLES AND FROM FISHERIES BYCATCH.
